Faculty of Advanced Science and Technology, Kumamoto University 2-39-1 Kurokami Chuo Kumamoto 860-8555 Japan Reducing the reliance on Pt group metals (PGMs) while enhancing the efficiency of three-way catalysts (TWCs) is a critical goal for emission control in modern hybrid engines. In this study, composite catalysts of Ni supported on ceria (Ni/CeO2) and Pt–Pd supported on ceria–zirconia mixed oxide (PtPd/CZ) were systematically investigated to maximize their synergy and minimize unfavorable interactions. After thermal aging at 800 °C under constant fuel-lean condition (L aging), a composite of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 in a 1:1 wt ratio exhibited superior low-temperature light-off TWC performance to that of PtPd/CZ alone, despite containing 50 % less PGMs. The preparations of composite catalysts in powder and honeycomb forms suggested that the synergistic effect of the components may be attributed to a high metal dispersion and synergistic interactions due to the optimal proximity between PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 during L aging. By contrast, the intimate contact between PGMs and the CeO2 surface overstabilized the PGM oxides, decreasing the activity. The positive interactions of the present composite catalyst were less obvious after thermal aging under stoichiometric–lean–rich fluctuating cycles because of PGM sintering. Overall, this study represents a significant advancement in PGM–Ni composite catalysts, paving the way toward more efficient and cost-effective TWC systems for next-generation hybrid engines. Graphical Abstract The composite catalysts of Ni/CeO2 and PtPd supported on ceria-zirconia (PtPd/CZ) were developed using different preparation pathways. The powder-mixed composite showed superior three-way catalysis activity with 50 % less platinum-group metals after thermal aging under a lean (L) condition due to the high dispersion and optimal proximity of active components. Keywords Three-way catalyst Composite catalyst Nickel Platinum group metals Cerium oxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the advancement of next-generation engines with higher efficiency for vehicle electrification and lean-burn combustion, a substantial reduction in the exhaust gas temperature is anticipated. Although this poses a challenge for exhaust purification during cold-start conditions, it allows reducing the thermal load on the catalyst, enabling the development of new three-way catalysts (TWCs). For instance, in contrast with conventional TWCs, which are typically designed to withstand temperatures up to 1000°C, reducing the maximum exhaust temperature to 800°C could lead to the development of catalysts with improved low-temperature activity by adopting alternative compositions and structures, including a reduced loading of the currently used expensive and scarce Pt group metals (PGMs) or using alternative transition metal elements. Among the most extensively studied 3d transition metals for TWCs, Cu-based catalysts exhibit excellent potential [1–21]. However, Cu-based catalysts cannot achieve complete NO conversion under standard TWC conditions, which limits their applicability [22]. In addition, although the combination of Cu with PGMs initially improves the TWC activity, severe deactivation occurs after thermal aging [23,24]. Under the reducing environment of thermal aging, the low melting point (1085°C) of metallic Cu facilitates its surface and gas-phase migration toward PGM particles and alloying, rendering Cu-based catalysts unsuitable to be combined with PGMs. Alternatively, Ni is another candidate as the active component of TWCs [25–32]. Wang et al. reported that Ni supported on ceria (Ni/CeO2) exhibited high catalytic activity toward the stoichiometric CO–NO reaction at low temperatures (<200°C) [25]. They proposed that N2 generation in this system proceeded via the removal of surface oxygen by adsorbed CO followed by the dissociation of NO on the resultant oxygen vacancy (VO) [26]. The remarkable performance of the Ni/CeO2 catalyst was attributed to the Ce3 + /Ce4+ redox couple facilitating oxygen release (VO generation) and storage (VO filling) near the NiO interface. Owing to the higher melting point of NiO (1955°C) compared with Cu oxides (CuO, 1326°C; Cu2O, 1235°C), Ni exhibits superior heat resistance to Cu. We previously studied the thermal stability of Ni/CeO2 at 900°C, finding that the intimate contact between NiO and CeO2 crystallites results in the formation of thermostable interfaces, where the perimeter in the vicinity provides active sites for removing and filling oxygen species in the catalytic CO–NO cycle [33]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the combination of Ni/CeO2 with PGMs for TWC applications has not been reported to date. In hybrid vehicles, although the engine is basically operated in a lean-burn mode, the combustion should be stoichiometric at cold-start. Hence, low-temperature stoichiometric TWC activity after thermal aging under a fuel-lean atmosphere is essential. To activate lean-aged catalysts at low temperature, Pt-based catalysts are especially suitable owing to the higher reducibility of Pt oxides compared with that of Pd and Rh oxides. The superior reducibility of Pt facilitates its regeneration under low-temperature conditions, enhancing the TWC performance during cold-start and after lean aging. In this study, aiming to develop a non-PGM–PGM composite catalyst with low-temperature TWC activity after lean aging, different preparation methods were examined to obtain composite catalysts by combining PtPd supported on ceria–zirconia (CeO2–ZrO2) mixed oxide (PtPd/CZ) with Ni/CeO2, furnishing PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite catalysts with optimal TWC performance after thermal aging. For practical applications, the PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite catalysts were coated onto a cordierite honeycomb using different layering strategies, and the activity of the resulting honeycomb-coated catalysts was evaluated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and thermal aging Aqueous solutions of Pt(NH3)2(NO2)2 and Pd(NO3)2 (Tanaka Precious Metals) were impregnated onto CeO2–ZrO2 (CZ; 46.5 mol% Ce, 46.5 mol% Zr, 1.7 mol% La, and 5.3 mol% Nd, Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo). The metal loadings were 1 wt% Pt and 0.4 wt% Pd. Similarly, a 5 wt% Ni/CeO2 catalyst was prepared using an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2 (Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemical Industries) and pure CeO2 powder (99.99 %, Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo). The impregnated solids were dried overnight at 110°C and then calcined at 600°C for 3 h in air. To prepare the composite catalyst, same weights of the as-prepared PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 powders were mixed mechanically using an agate mortar and pestle for 10 min, affording a powder mixture (hereinafter denoted as powder mix). For comparison, two other types of composite catalysts were prepared via granule mixing and sequential impregnation, respectively. In the granule mixing, each catalyst powder was hydraulically pressed into a pellet under 40 MPa and crashed into 20-mesh granules, which were packed together in the catalyst bed to afford a sample denoted as granule mix. In the sequential impregnation, mixed powders of CZ and CeO2 in a 1:1 wt ratio were impregnated with 5 wt% Ni to obtain Ni/(CZ+CeO2), followed by a second impregnation with 0.5 wt% Pt and 0.2 wt% Pd. The as-obtained PtPd/Ni/(CZ+CeO2) catalyst was denoted as imp. In all the cases, the PGM content in the composites was the same, i.e., 0.5 wt% Pt and 0.2 wt% Pd. Miniature honeycomb catalysts coated with the as-prepared catalysts were prepared using a dipping procedure [34–36]. Mixtures of catalyst powder, colloidal ZrO2 sol (Nissan Chemical Industries) as a binder, and distilled ion-exchanged water were ball-milled at ambient temperature into a homogeneous slurry. The solid-to-water weight ratio was set to 0.1. The as-prepared slurry was coated onto a honeycomb-shaped cordierite substrate (ϕ 10 mm × 10 mm, 600 cells in−2, NGK Insulators) via dip-coating. After drying at 110°C in an oven, the coated honeycomb structures were air-calcined at 600°C. The dipping procedure was repeated until the desired amount of washcoat layer per unit volume of the honeycomb (220 g L−1) was reached. Three types of honeycomb-coated catalysts consisting of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 were prepared as shown in Table S1. Monolayer-coated honeycombs were prepared using a mixed slurry of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2. Bilayer-coated honeycombs were prepared via a stepwise dipping process. First, the cordierite honeycomb was dipped into a slurry containing Ni/CeO2. After calcining at 600°C for 3 h in air, a second dipping was conducted using a slurry containing PtPd/CZ. Another bilayer structure was prepared similarly but with the reverse order of stepwise coating. In addition, a Rh–Pd bilayer-coated honeycomb, mimicking commercialized TWCs was prepared as a reference honeycomb catalyst. Details on the coating layers of these honeycomb catalysts are listed in Table S1. The as-prepared powder and honeycomb catalysts were thermally aged at 800°C for 5 h under simulated aging conditions. The composition of the gas feed was fixed at a constant fuel-lean condition (L aging) or fluctuated in a stoichiometric (S, 40 s), fuel-lean (L, 10 s), and fuel-rich (R, 10 s) sequence (SLR aging). The catalysts were heated from room temperature to 800°C for 2 h under a N2 flow. When the target temperature of 800°C was reached, N2 was replaced with an L or SLR gas stream as shown in Fig. S1. The simulated gas streams contained 0.05 % NO, 0.5 % CO, 0.04 % C3H6, 10 % H2O, and different concentrations of O2, balanced by N2 supplied at 100 cm3 min−1. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was conducted under monochromated Cu–Kα radiation (20 mA and 30 kV; Multiflex, Rigaku). X-ray fluorescence (EDXL300, Rigaku) was used to analyze the metal loading. The results agreed with the expected values within the experimental error. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using a K-Alpha spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with monochromated Al Kα radiation (1486.7 eV). The binding energies were calibrated using that of the C1s signal (285.0 eV) originating from adventitious carbon. The nanostructure of the catalysts was analyzed using scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray mapping performed on a JEM-ARM200F (JEOL) apparatus operating with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and X-ray images of a cross-sectional specimen of the honeycomb catalyst were obtained by electron probe microanalysis (EPMA, Shimadzu EPMA-1720HT, 15 kV). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area (S BET) of catalysts was determined from N2 physisorption isotherms at −196°C using a Belsorp Mini apparatus (Microtrac BEL). The amount of CO chemisorbed onto the catalysts was determined using the pulsed injection method at 50°C with a Belcat-B apparatus (Microtrac BEL). The catalyst was pretreated with H2 at 200 °C and then preinjected with CO2 at 50°C to avoid overestimation caused by CO adsorption onto CeO2 and/or CZ [37]. The equilibrium partial oxygen pressure and temperature plots of the PGM–O systems were thermodynamically calculated using commercially available software (HSC Chemistry, Outokumpu Research Oy). 2.3 Catalytic reaction The thermally aged powder catalyst was subjected to TWC light-off tests in a flow microreactor using granulated catalyst powders (W = 50 mg) packed in a quartz tube with an inner diameter of 4 mm. The catalyst bed was heated from 100°C to 600°C at a constant rate of 10°C min−1. A stoichiometric simulated exhaust gas mixture of 0.05 % NO, 0.5 % CO, 0.04 % C3H6, 0.4 % O2, and 5 % H2O diluted in He was fed to the catalyst at a flow rate (F) of 100 cm3 min−1 (W/F = 5.0 × 10−4 g min cm−3). The concentrations in the effluent gas from the catalyst bed were analyzed online using Horiba VA-3000 nondispersive infrared detectors for NO, CO and C3H6, and an O2 sensor (JKO-O2LD3, Jikco). The catalytic performance of honeycomb catalysts was evaluated using a Horiba SIGU/MEXA reaction analysis system consisting of a gas supply unit, an infrared image furnace, and a gas analysis unit. The catalytic light-off test was performed by heating the catalyst bed from 100°C to 600°C at a rate of 10°C min−1 while supplying a stoichiometric mixture of 0.05 % NO, 0.5 % CO, 0.05 % C3H6, 0.44 % O2, 10 % CO2, 10 % H2O, and N2 balance at a flow rate of 1.3 L min−1 (space velocity = 1 × 105 h−1) under atmospheric pressure. Gas analysis was performed using nondispersive infrared CO/CO2 detectors, a flame ionization hydrocarbon detector, a chemiluminescence NOx (NO + NO2) detector, and a magnetopneumatic O2 detector. These catalytic light-off runs for powder and honeycomb catalysts were repeated three times. The catalyst performance was evaluated using the results obtained for the second light-off run because they remained virtually unchanged compared with those of the third run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 TWC light-off activity of thermally aged composite catalysts We recently reported that a Ni/CeO2 catalyst maintained its high catalytic activity for the CO–NO reaction even after thermal aging at 900°C for 25 h in air [33]. In the present study, the catalytic performance of thermally aged Ni/CeO2 was tested under stoichiometric TWC conditions. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the NO reduction activity of the catalyst was negligible at temperatures ≤ 400°C, suggesting the complete inhibition of the CO–NO reaction owing to the presence of O2. By contrast, CO oxidation occurred at temperatures ≥ 150°C, followed by C3H6 oxidation starting at temperatures ≥ 250°C. This result was observed irrespective of the type of thermal aging atmosphere, i.e., L or SLR, because the Ni species existed as NiO in both cases, as described below. Since the NO reduction activity of Ni/CeO2 under TWC conditions was negligible, the combination with PGM catalysts was examined next. Considering the aforementioned lowest possible light-off temperatures after L aging as a priority, Pt-based PGM components were selected for the combination with Ni/CeO2. Thermodynamic calculations predicted that Pt oxides are less stable than Pd and Rh oxides (Fig. S2) and can be immediately reduced to the active metallic state upon exposure to a stoichiometric gas mixture of NO, CO, and hydrocarbons. Nonetheless, Pt exhibits lower NO reduction activity in TWC than Pd and Rh [38]. On the basis of these considerations and the preliminary screening results described in Fig. S3, PtPd/CZ consisting of 1 wt% Pt and 0.4 wt% Pd co-impregnated on CZ was selected as a counterpart of Ni/CeO2 in the composite. A CZ support was used for Pt and Pd to achieve a fast oxygen release–storage function, which is beneficial for accelerating the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons at low temperatures [34,35]. As shown in Fig. 1(b), PtPd/CZ after L aging at 800°C showed efficient TWC light-off activity for NO, CO, and C3H6. A powder mixture of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 at a 1:1 wt ratio was used as a composite catalyst after L aging at 800°C. To estimate the advantage of the composite catalyst, a mixture of 25 mg of PtPd/CZ and 25 mg of Ni/CeO2 (a total of 50 mg) was compared with 50 mg of PtPd/CZ (Fig. 1(b)). As shown in Fig. 1(c), the most remarkable activity enhancement was observed for CO, whereas the C3H6 and NO light-off curves were also shifted toward lower temperatures. The light-off for CO commenced at the lowest temperature (≥100°C), followed by C3H6 and subsequently NO. This sequence was more obvious over the composite catalyst than over PtPd/CZ alone, suggesting the major contribution of Ni/CeO2 to the low-temperature CO conversion. It should be noted that the NO reduction activity of PtPd/CZ was also enhanced by mixing with Ni/CeO2, which exhibited negligible activity (Fig. 1(a)). These results imply that the synergistic effect between PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 occurred during L aging. In contrast with the synergistic enhancement in the PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite, the activity was degraded when PtPd/CZ was mixed only with CeO2 and then thermally aged under the L condition (Fig. 1(d)). Therefore, loading Ni onto CeO2 is indispensable to enhance the TWC activity of PtPd/CZ at low temperatures. The TWC light-off test was also conducted after thermal aging under the fluctuating SLR cycle condition at 800°C (see Fig. S4 for each light-off data). The temperatures required to convert 50 % of each gas (T 50) in these catalytic tests are compared with those of the L-aged catalysts in the bar chart displayed in Fig. 2. The superiority of the composite catalyst was less obvious after SLR aging, especially for the NO and C3H6 conversion efficiencies, with the T 50 values being slightly higher than those of PtPd/CZ. Despite containing half the amount of PGMs, the activity of the composite catalyst was enhanced over that of PtPd/CZ after L aging. This result suggests that the combination of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 is a promising catalyst candidate toward the adaptation to lean-burn engines for series hybrid vehicles. 3.2 Effect of the composite preparation procedure To identify the most effective composite for achieving low-temperature TWC light-off activity, different mixing procedures were evaluated. Fig. 3 compares the T 50 values for the NO, CO, and C3H6 conversions during a simulated TWC reaction over PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composites prepared using different mixing procedures, i.e., powder mix, granule mix, and imp, and subjected to thermal aging (see Fig. S5 for the light-off data). L and SLR aging induced a similar increasing trend for T 50, i.e., (powder mix) < (granule mix) < (imp). Since these catalysts have almost the similar overall composition, the difference in catalytic activity may result from the proximity between the two catalyst components PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2, which is most likely greater for powder mix than for granule mix. However, although the sequential impregnation of PGMs and Ni in the imp catalyst should provide the closest proximity between PtPd and Ni, it afforded the worst TWC performance in Fig. 3. This complex correlation between activity and component proximity suggests that both favorable and unfavorable interactions may occur in the composite catalysts, although the detailed mechanism of these contrasting interactions is still unclear, but further discussed in the next section. As shown in Fig. 3, the powder mix and granule mix catalysts after SLR aging showed increased T 50 values relative to the L-aged samples, reflecting a decrease in catalytic activity. As discussed in the next section, this trend can be rationalized by the faster sintering of PGMs under the SLR condition. Nevertheless, the powder mix catalyst still outperformed the others. To further assess the preparation procedure of the PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite in a more practical honeycomb structure, the catalyst powders were coated employing both monolayer and bilayer configurations as schematically shown in Fig. 4 and Table S1. As shown in Fig. 4(a), catalysts were coated on a miniature-sized cordierite honeycomb (ϕ10 mm×10 mm) with a cell density of 600 cells per square inch. The elemental distribution within these coated catalysts was investigated using EPMA, and the results are shown in Fig. 4(b). The X-ray elemental mapping revealed a homogeneous distribution of Pt, Pd, and Ni in the monolayer composite. In contrast, distinct layers of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 were observed in the bilayer configuration regardless of the layering order, confirming the successful deposition of the individual catalysts. Subsequently, their TWC light-off activity was evaluated under a simulated stoichiometric TWC atmosphere (Fig. S6) using a Rh−Pd bilayer catalyst similar to commercialized TWCs as a reference (Table S1). It should be noted that the three types of composite catalysts contained 25 % less PGMs than the reference catalyst. Fig. 5 compares the T 50 values for the TWC light-off over honeycomb catalysts with different configurations. Among the L-aged catalysts, the monolayer composite showed a considerably improved performance compared with the bilayer composite catalysts. The higher performance indicates that the proximity between the two catalyst components PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 within the same washcoat layer is an essential factor, which is in accordance with the result of the powder catalysts (Fig. 3). Furthermore, the monolayer composite outperformed the reference catalyst, despite containing 25 % less PGMs and lacking Rh, which is the most scarce and expensive PGM. After SLR aging, the superiority of the monolayer composite was less pronounced than that of the powder catalysts. However, the T 50 values for the NO and C3H6 conversions were still comparable to those of the reference, and the T 50 for CO conversion was much lower. These results suggest that the monolayer PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite honeycomb catalyst offers a promising cost-effective solution for efficient emission control systems. 3.3 Structural characterization of thermally aged composite catalysts The present results suggest that the observed enhancement in catalytic performance could be related to the component proximity in the composite catalysts and its change during the aging process, which should affect the metal dispersion, metal oxidation state, or interactions between components. To explore these factors and their correlation with the observed activity trends, the powder PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 catalyst was characterized using CO chemisorption, XRD, XPS, and STEM. The CO chemisorption analysis provided information about the Pt and Pd dispersion in the composite because the CO uptake was negligible over Ni/CeO2 alone. As shown in Table 1, fresh PtPd/CZ showed the large CO uptake of ca. 120 cm3 g-PGM−1, which decreased to ca. 33 cm3 g-PGM−1 and ca. 7 cm3 g-PGM−1 after L and SLR aging, respectively, suggesting different degrees of sintering. Although the fresh PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite catalyst (powder mix) showed a smaller CO uptake (ca. 103 cm3 g-PGM−1), the values for the thermally aged composites were more than twice those of PtPd/CZ. Considering the similar S BET values of L-aged catalysts, this enhancement in CO chemisorption capacity can be invoked to explain the higher catalytic performance of the composite catalyst. The smaller S BET values of SLR-aged catalysts than those of L-aged ones imply accelerated sintering of CZ and CeO2 under repeating reduction and oxidation cycles. Notably, the imp catalyst showed the largest values of CO uptake despite the worst TWC light-off performance in Fig. 3. This contradiction may be associated with the preferential impregnation of PGMs precursors (Pt(NH3)2(NO2)2 and/or Pd(NO3)2) onto CeO2 rather than CZ. Actually, a similar result was obtained when PGMs were impregnated onto CeO2 or CZ alone, whether with and without Ni loaded. PtPd/Ni/CeO2 (L-aged) showed CO uptake of 83 cm3 g-PGM−1, which was two and a half-fold larger than that of PtPd/Ni/CZ (33 cm3 g-PGM−1). This means the higher dispersion of PGMs on CeO2 rather than CZ after thermal aging, owing to stronger metal-support interactions. Nevertheless, this interaction with CeO2 overstabilized the oxidation state of PGMs and thus delayed the evolution of active metallic surface during the stoichiometric TWC light-off. This is a possible reason for the higher T 50 for the imp catalyst. The unfavorable interaction in the imp catalyst was also supported by XPS results as shown in Fig. S7. The spectral feature of the imp catalyst indicated that PGMs are mainly supported on CeO2 rather than CZ. A similar interaction happened when PtPd/CZ was mixed with bare CeO2 and thermally aged (Fig. 1d). Furthermore, previous studies reported that the contact between PGMs and CeO2 under high-temperature oxidizing atmosphere leads to a strong interaction via Pd–O–Ce bonding, overstabilizing the Pd oxide state [39,40]. Such an interaction can be expected to occur in the imp catalyst after L aging, but is less likely in the powder mix and granule mix catalysts because PGMs were impregnated only onto CZ. The XRD patterns of the Ni/CeO2 catalyst before and after L and SLR aging ( Fig. 6) revealed the presence of CeO2 and NiO phases, with no remarkable phase changes upon aging under either of the conditions. However, a noticeable sharpening of the CeO2 diffraction peaks was observed after L and SLR aging at 800°C, indicating that thermal sintering led to crystallite growth. The XRD of the PtPd/CZ catalyst (Fig. 6) showed diffraction peaks only for CZ, without any observable peaks for Pt, Pd, or their oxides, probably due to their high dispersion state. After L aging at 800°C, metallic Pt peaks appeared because exposure to the high-temperature aging atmosphere reduced the Pt oxide to metal particles. In addition, the SLR aging yielded more intense Pt peaks at slightly higher 2θ values, suggesting the formation of a PtPd alloy with a larger crystallite size. The PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 (powder mix) catalyst showed diffraction peaks for NiO, CeO2, and CZ, confirming the occurrence of crystallite growth of CeO2 upon aging like in PtPd/CZ. Conversely, CZ was more stable against sintering. After L and SLR aging, peaks for metallic Pt and PtPd alloys appeared, respectively, but no peaks corresponding to metallic Ni or Ni–PGM alloys were observed, suggesting that NiO remained unchanged under the aging conditions. These results were in accord with those of the XPS analyses (Fig. S8). The structure and elemental dispersion at the nanoscale were studied using STEM and X-ray mapping. Fig. 7 displays darkfield STEM and X-ray images of L-aged PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 (powder mix). Although the Ni oxide was observed as independent particles with a size of 15–40 nm, no isolated Pt or Pd was identified. The highly dispersed Pt and Pd species were in contact not only with CZ but also with Ni/CeO2, implying a considerable migration during L aging. In our previous study [33], NiO and CeO2 crystallites were in intimate contact, forming thermostable interfaces, where the perimeter in the vicinity provided the active sites for the catalytic CO–NO cycle. Therefore, the migration of PGMs to the NiO/CeO2 interface may play a key role in the TWC activity enhancement observed in the present study. In the SLR-aged composite ( Fig. 8), independent PGMs particles with a size of about 20 nm were observed. The overlaying mapping of Pt, Pd, and Ni shown at the bottom of Fig. 8 suggests that Pt and Pd species merged into one another, implying the formation of a PtPd alloy, whereas Ni species shared an interface with the PtPd alloy. These results are consistent with the XRD and CO chemisorption results. The absence of Ni–PGM alloys is contrast to our previous study on Cu oxide–PGM composite catalysts, which revealed that Cu–PGM alloying under SLR aging led to severe deactivation in TWC reactions [23]. Under TWC conditions (≥800°C), Cu oxides (CuO and Cu2O) are much more easily reduced to the metallic state, which has a higher vapor pressure and hence mobility toward the PGM species, leading to alloying. However, NiO is stable even under the TWC conditions; therefore, unfavorable interactions with PGM are unlikely. The copresence of highly dispersed and stable NiO and metallic PGMs is a characteristic feature of the present composite catalyst. On the basis of the optimized structure of the PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite revealed in the present study, further work will focus on elucidating the synergistic effect of each component on the TWC performance. 4 Conclusion In this study, a PGM–Ni composite catalyst was systematically investigated. A mixture of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 in a 1:1 wt ratio was prepared in powder form. After thermal aging at 800°C under a lean condition, the composite catalyst exhibited superior low-temperature TWC light-off performance to PtPd/CZ alone, despite the former containing 50 % less PGMs. Among the different PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite types, the composite prepared via powder mixing outperformed those prepared via granule mixing or direct impregnation of Pt, Pd, and Ni onto a mixture of CZ and CeO2. A promising catalyst was also prepared by coating the PtPd/CZ+Ni/CeO2 composite onto a honeycomb-shaped cordierite substrate. Notably, monolayer coating resulted in higher activity compared with the separate coating of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 as a bilayer, outperforming a reference catalyst consisting of Rh and Pd. The enhanced activity may be attributed to the high metal dispersion and synergistic interactions stemming from the optimal proximity between PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 during L aging. Although further investigation is needed to confirm this hypothesis, the present results underscore the beneficial role of Ni/CeO2 in enhancing PGM-based catalytic systems. Overall, this study provides new insights into PGM–Ni composite catalysts, paving the way toward more efficient and cost-effective TWC systems for next-generation hybrid engines. coredata.dc:description: Reducing the reliance on Pt group metals (PGMs) while enhancing the efficiency of three-way catalysts (TWCs) is a critical goal for emission control in modern hybrid engines. In this study, composite catalysts of Ni supported on ceria (Ni/CeO2) and Pt–Pd supported on ceria–zirconia mixed oxide (PtPd/CZ) were systematically investigated to maximize their synergy and minimize unfavorable interactions. After thermal aging at 800 °C under constant fuel-lean condition (L aging), a composite of PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 in a 1:1 wt ratio exhibited superior low-temperature light-off TWC performance to that of PtPd/CZ alone, despite containing 50 % less PGMs. The preparations of composite catalysts in powder and honeycomb forms suggested that the synergistic effect of the components may be attributed to a high metal dispersion and synergistic interactions due to the optimal proximity between PtPd/CZ and Ni/CeO2 during L aging. By contrast, the intimate contact between PGMs and the CeO2 surface overstabilized the PGM oxides, decreasing the activity. The positive interactions of the present composite catalyst were less obvious after thermal aging under stoichiometric–lean–rich fluctuating cycles because of PGM sintering. Overall, this study represents a significant advancement in PGM–Ni composite catalysts, paving the way toward more efficient and cost-effective TWC systems for next-generation hybrid engines.
